title: VivoAquatics NextGen Mobile Platform Suspension Plan

sections.title: Purpose of the Document
content: This document is designed to meticulously guide the temporary suspension of the VivoAquatics Next Generation Mobile Platform. Its primary aim is to ensure a smooth and organized transition into this hiatus, effectively minimizing operational risks and safeguarding all critical components of the project. This plan addresses various technical and managerial aspects, from software development to stakeholder communication, ensuring comprehensive coverage of all necessary suspension activities.

sections.title: Overview of the Project
content: VivoAquatics Next Generation Mobile Platform: An advanced mobile solution designed to enhance aquatic management and chemical control systems.

sections.title: Current Stage
content: The platform is currently in the final stages of alpha development, ready for Beta testing. .

sections.title: Challenges and Opportunities
content: The decision to temporarily suspend the project arises from delays in the production timeline. The primary component preventing moving forward at this time being a lack of integration with the core environment.

sections.title: Looking Forward
content: The suspension plan is devised with a forward-looking approach, considering the eventual resumption of the project. It includes detailed strategies for maintaining the platform's core components during the hiatus and a robust resumption plan to seamlessly transition back into full-scale development and deployment.

sections.title: Expo Platform
content: Expo is an open-source platform for making universal native apps for Android, iOS, and the web with JavaScript and React. It simplifies the development process by enabling developers to build, deploy, and quickly iterate on iOS and Android apps from the same codebase.

sections.title: Apple iOS & TestFlight
content: iOS is the operating system that runs on Apple's mobile devices, such as iPhones and iPads. TestFlight is an online service for over-the-air installation and testing of mobile applications, provided by Apple. It allows developers to send beta builds of their iOS apps to testers and receive feedback before the apps are released on the App Store.

sections.title: Android & Play Store
content: Android is a mobile operating system developed by Google, designed primarily for touchscreen mobile devices such as smartphones and tablets. The Google Play Store is the official app store for Android devices, providing a platform for users to download apps and games and for developers to distribute and monetize their Android applications.

sections.title: Mongo DB
content: MongoDB is a popular, open-source NoSQL database that uses a document-oriented data model and a non-structured query language. It's known for its scalability, flexibility, and ability to handle large volumes of data and complex queries, making it a suitable choice for a wide range of applications.

sections.title: AWS Kubernetes
content: Server clusters hosting the GraphQL data services reside in Amazon Web Services in Kubernetes Clusters. These clusters were created using Terraform, and are managed by AWS, with auto-scaling and auto-recovery.

sections.title: GitHub
content: GitHub is a web-based version-control and collaboration platform for software developers. It allows individuals and teams to track changes in code, collaborate on software projects, and host their source code repositories. GitHub also provides access control, task management, bug tracking, and feature request functionalities.

sections.title: Project Status
content: In its current state, three projects have been built to support Android and iOS builds and submissions to their respective platforms. Production, development and testing. Builds, updates and submissions to Apple and Android are automated from GitHub CICD workflows.

sections.title: Project Status
content: Currently, three database deployments exist in Mongo DB for the project. Two are currently used for dev, uat and sandbox. One is used for production.

sections.title: Costs & Fees
content: Free Tier: MongoDB Atlas offers a free tier, which is often suitable for small-scale applications, development, and testing. If your database is on this tier and fits within the free tier limitations (like storage and compute resources), there will be no ongoing costs.

Paid Plans: For paid plans, the cost is typically based on the resources you provision, such as storage, memory, data transfer, and backup storage. Even if there is no activity. Consider if removing the database instances no longer being used would reduce or remove costs.

Pausing Clusters: MongoDB allows pausing clusters. When paused, storage costs may still be incurred (but reduced), and compute charges are typically halted. This feature can be useful for reducing costs while frozen.
Monitoring and Other Features: Costs may also be associated with additional features like enhanced monitoring, dedicated support, or security features, depending on your subscription.
